Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Practiced spoken and written Chinese as well as reading and listening comprehension, topics in contemporary Chinese society like climate change, senior care, marriage and leftover men, and the HIV public health crisis.
This course helped me refine my formal Chinese language ability in terms of a reading and writing perspective.
You learn a lot of new vocabulary that allows you to converse about a myriad of social topics relevant to China.

This course is extremely useful for the acquisition of vocabulary in the realms of media and news. We learn very pertinent idioms and have been able to develop spoken proficiencyand collaboration through presentations in groups.
I learned more complex Chinese vocabulary.

The course is very self-directed and large, which is both a strength and a weakness. You could get by fine without doing much of the work and speaking a handful of times when the professor cold calls you, but if you really put the work in you'll get a lot of the class, both in terms of knowledge and language skills. Could feel a bit impersonal. Readings aren't from textbooks but actual news articles and op-eds, which is nice. Important phrases and sayings are always explained thoroughly, which is nice as well.
This course was very good all around. I think that the nature of the material covered was highly relevant and I enjoyed having the opportunity to talk about it in class.
The professor is the strength. Zhou Laoshi cares so much about his students and his teaching reflects that.

The course is graded in a way that is tailored towards the individual levels of each student as each student is of different levels. The readings are digestible and interesting. Perhaps the scheduling of presentations could be improved as they usually clash with other deadlines, but other than that I have no major qualms with the course.

The course material is interesting and a great way to improve ones reading comprehension. The strength is no doubt the professor; Zhou laoshi is a caring and approachable teacher who always thinks of the students  wellbeing first. Im so glad to have met him and shared a semester of Chinese with him!

Weakness - class could have been more stimulating
Strength - very enjoyable
Great class, Zhou Laoshi is amazing.
Yes! The topics we learned in this class were so interesting and relevant to the world today. The instructor is amazing too.
Yes, if you have the time and self-discipline to finish all the readings and actually participate in class discussions.
I would recommend this course to any student studying Chinese and who is looking to apply their knowledge of the language to a description of current events.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wishes to further their study of Chinese.

Yes. This course will help develop your Chinese in a stressful free manner. Zhou Laoshi is a compassionate and caring teacher that looks out for the well-being if evey student and provides constructive feedback. The readings are interesting and provide interesting insights into Chinese culture while the students acquires new vocabulary and proficiency in the language
Yes
Yes -- an amazing Chinese class. Relatively low time commitment with high learning outcome.
Yes! If not for the topics of the course, then take it for Prof. Zhou! He is amazing :)
